items.title: TikTok threatens to go offline if Biden doesn't intervene
items.author: Alex Heath
items.summary:
- TikTok plans to go offline on January 19 unless the Biden administration intervenes.
- The company requests a definitive statement ensuring its service providers, like Apple and Google, won't be liable for breaking the law.
- The Supreme Court recently upheld a ban unless TikTok's parent company, ByteDance, divests its ownership.
- The White House has indicated that the decision will be left to President-elect Trump, who is set to take office on January 20.
- The Department of Justice supports the ban, citing national security concerns.

items.title: CBS considers caving on Trump censorship lawsuit to save Paramount merger
items.author: Richard Lawler
items.summary:
- Donald Trump has filed a $10 billion lawsuit against CBS over the editing of a 60 Minutes interview with Kamala Harris.
- CBS' parent company, Paramount Global, is considering settling the lawsuit as it faces a government review of its merger with Skydance.
- Incoming FCC chairman Brendan Carr has warned that presidential dissatisfaction with CBS News could complicate the merger review process.
- The lawsuit claims CBS used deceptive practices in reporting on Harris’ response to a question about the war in Gaza.
- Paramount may follow other media companies like Disney in settling legal issues ahead of political changes.

items.title: How TikTok backed itself into a corner
items.author: Alex Heath
items.summary:
- TikTok is in a precarious position after losing a Supreme Court appeal concerning a potential ban.
- The company initially dismissed the notion of a ban and now relies on possible intervention from Donald Trump.
- TikTok invested over $1 billion in 'Project Texas' to address US data concerns, but this was initiated without government approval.
- Project Texas has isolated US data in infrastructure managed by Oracle, which may soon be legally unable to collaborate with TikTok.
- Shutting down the app in the US could be easier than removing it from app stores.
- Despite uncertainties, TikTok's leadership maintains an optimistic facade about navigating the ban situation.

items.title: Instagram profile grids are going to feature rectangles instead of squares
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- Instagram is changing profile grids from squares to rectangles as part of a rollout happening over the weekend.
- CEO Adam Mosseri explained the change is due to the increasing number of vertical photos and videos being uploaded.
- Mosseri acknowledged the transitional pain but believes users will appreciate seeing their content as intended.
- The change follows a limited test that occurred back in August 2024.
- Instagram is also introducing a feature to view videos liked by friends in the Reels feed.

items.title: AT&T pulls its 5G internet service in NY over new affordable internet law
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- AT&T has announced it will discontinue its [5G Internet Air service](https://www.theverge.com/2025/1/17/24346159/att-new-york-affordable-broadband-act-5g) in New York due to the state’s [Affordable Broadband Act](https://www.nysenate.gov/legislation/bills/2021/A6259) becoming effective.
- Existing users will have 45 days to transition to another provider without charges.
- The Affordable Broadband Act requires large providers to offer two affordable plans for low-income households, citing download speeds of 25Mbps for $15 and up to 200Mbps for $20.
- AT&T's Internet Air provided speeds of 40 to 140Mbps for $55 per month but chose to exit the market instead of adjusting to regulatory compliance.
- The law had been delayed due to pushback but was upheld after the US Supreme Court declined to intervene in December.
- AT&T argues that the law creates unsustainable rate regulations preventing future investment in broadband infrastructure.

items.title: Bumble founder Whitney Wolfe Herd returns as CEO amid a dating app decline
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
• Whitney Wolfe Herd returns as CEO of Bumble in mid-March 2025 after stepping down in early 2024.
• Former CEO Lidiane Jones resigned for personal reasons and will stay until Herd's return.
• Bumble introduced a redesign allowing men to send the first message, following a significant drop in share price post-redesign.
• The dating app market has faced recent struggles, including a decline in user engagement as reported by Match Group.
• Bumble's recent earnings showed an increase in paying users but a drop in average revenue per user and total revenue.
• Surveys indicate growing concerns over scams and negative experiences with dating apps, particularly among women.

items.title: Nintendo omits original Donkey Kong Country Returns team from the remaster’s credits
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- The launch of Donkey Kong Country Returns HD did not credit the original Retro Studios team members.
- Nintendo has addressed the omission, stating they value all contributions in game development.
- Crediting issues have been a recurrent problem in the industry, with previous controversies involving Metroid Prime and external translators.

items.title: Automakers sue to block Biden’s ‘flawed’ automatic emergency braking rule
items.author: Andrew J. Hawkins
items.summary:
- The Alliance of Automotive Innovation filed a lawsuit against a new rule mandating automatic emergency braking (AEB) by 2029.
- Major automakers including Ford, GM, and Toyota are represented in the suit, aiming to repeal the regulation they describe as “flawed.”
- The rule requires vehicles to automatically stop to avoid collisions at speeds up to 62mph and detect pedestrians at various speeds.
- NHTSA stated the rule is practicable and necessary for increasing safety standards in new vehicles.
- The auto alliance claims current technology cannot meet the requirements and prefers a previous voluntary agreement on AEB implementation.
- Consumer advocates support the rule, arguing it is crucial for roadway safety and should be achievable by the 2029 deadline.

items.title: Castlevania: Nocturne’s second season is another soft-spoken knockout
items.author: Charles Pulliam-Moore
items.summary:
- Season 2 continues the story from Season 1, focusing on Richter Belmont's fight against Erzsebet Báthory during the French Revolution.
- The narrative emphasizes personal struggles and relationships amidst the backdrop of war and political unrest.
- Key characters like Erzsebet and Drolta face moral conflicts, highlighting the theme of personal transformation in the face of violence.
- The visual quality of the season is praised, particularly during action scenes, adding to the overall storytelling.
- Despite strong character development, some characters, like Annette, are noted to have less screen time compared to others.
- Season 2 is now available for streaming on Netflix, continuing its reputation as a standout video game adaptation.

items.title: SpaceX’s fiery Starship explosion put on a fantastic show but delayed and diverted flights
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- The SpaceX Starship explosion created a colorful debris display, resembling a meteor shower.
- The incident delayed flights, with the FAA diverting planes around the debris field.
- The explosion occurred 8.5 minutes after launch, following a separation from the booster.
- The launch was a test of a redesigned propulsion system and featured a reused Raptor engine.
- SpaceX suggests the explosion might have been caused by a fire in the ship’s rear section.
- Initial data indicates that debris fell within a designated hazard area, minimizing the risk.
- The event led to flight delays of up to 45 minutes from Miami and Fort Lauderdale airports.

items.title: Here’s how to play the Switch 2 early
items.author: Ash Parrish
items.summary:
- Nintendo is offering previews of the Switch 2 at live events across North America, Europe, and Asia.
- Demo cities include New York, Los Angeles, Dallas, and Toronto; registration details can be found on Nintendo’s website.
- Attendees must have a Nintendo account, and registration opens on January 17th, closing on January 26th.
- Tickets are free but awarded by lottery; only one time slot can be registered for per participant.

items.title: Microsoft triples down on AI
items.author: Tom Warren
items.summary:
- Microsoft announced the formation of a new AI engineering group called CoreAI, led by Jay Parikh, to enhance its AI platform and tools.
- The company introduced pay-as-you-go agents for its relaunched Copilot Chat and bundled AI features into Microsoft 365, raising subscription prices by $3 per month.
- Microsoft aims to automate services traditionally performed by humans, shifting from software-as-a-service to service-as-software, while addressing concerns from employees about the emphasis on AI.

items.title: It’s perfectly fine to ignore your smartwatch this January
items.author: Victoria Song
items.summary:
• January is the peak time for fitness tech companies to market New Year's resolutions.
• Introduction of "Quitter’s day", the second Friday in January when many abandon their resolutions, prompting Apple to release a motivational ad.
• The author experienced personal challenges at CES, highlighting the pressures of fitness tracking and reminders.
• Many quit their resolutions due to unrealistic expectations, not because of the technology itself.
• The author suggests turning off wearable notifications and trusting oneself in fitness journeys.

items.title: Prime members can save $50 on the Amazon Kindle Colorsoft in its first sale
items.author: Quentyn Kennemer
items.summary:
- The Kindle Colorsoft Signature Edition has dropped to $229.99, a $50 discount, for Prime members.
- It is Amazon’s first e-reader with a color display, featuring 32GB storage, waterproofing, and wireless charging support.
- The 7-inch display offers superior color reproduction but has a maximum resolution of 300ppi that reduces when using color.
- The battery life is advertised at eight weeks, shorter than the Paperwhite’s twelve weeks.
- Some early units suffered from a yellow discoloration issue, which Amazon claims to have fixed with hardware and software updates.

items.title: A giant battery power plant is on fire in California
items.author: Justine Calma
items.summary:
- A fire broke out at the Moss Landing Energy Storage Facility, the largest battery power plant in the world.
- Evacuation orders were issued for nearby residents, and parts of Highway 1 were closed.
- County health officials advised residents to shelter indoors and close windows and doors.
- Monterey County Supervisor described the situation as a disaster.
- Vistra will investigate the fire’s cause once it is under control.
- The facility expanded in 2023, adding over 110,000 battery modules for renewable energy storage.
- This incident follows previous battery fires in the area, including one at a PG&E facility in 2022.

items.title: Lawmakers press Meta, Apple, Google, and others on massive Trump donations
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Sens. Elizabeth Warren and Michael Bennet are questioning major tech firms about their $1 million donations to President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration fund.
- Companies including Google, Microsoft, Apple, Meta, Amazon, and OpenAI made these donations to potentially avoid regulatory scrutiny.
- The donations are notably higher than those made to President Joe Biden's 2021 inauguration.
- Lawmakers emphasize concerns about corporate influence over the Trump administration and have requested responses from the companies by January 30th.

items.title: Some of the Switch’s 2 first accessories are all about Mario Kart
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Nacon has revealed a folding desktop steering wheel accessory for the Switch 2’s redesigned Joy-Cons.
- The accessory will be priced at around $30.
- Other accessories announced include carrying cases, screen protectors, silicone wraps, and chargers designed for the Switch 2's ergonomic use in racing games.
- The next entry in the Mario Kart series was teased during the Switch 2 reveal, with more details expected in April 2025.
- Accessories are available on Nacon’s UK site but not for preorder or with shipping dates yet.

items.title: Instagram will show your friends what Reels you’ve liked
items.author: Mia Sato
items.summary:
- Instagram introduces a new tab in the Reels feed displaying videos liked by friends.
- This feature is reminiscent of the old activity feed removed in 2019.
- Instagram aims to enhance social interaction over content shared among friends.
- Users can see which friends liked a post and left notes on Reels.
- Concerns raised about privacy and users' willingness to share their likes publicly.
- Competitive context with TikTok, as Reels attempts to draw users in during potential TikTok ban.

items.title: The Ring Battery Doorbell Pro, one of our favorite video doorbells, is cheaper than ever
items.author: Sheena Vasani
items.summary:
- The Ring Battery Doorbell Pro is on sale for $149.99, a discount of $80, available until February 1st at 12:59AM ET.
- Features include 1536p video, motion detection with three sensors, color night vision, dual-band Wi-Fi, and smart responses.
- Subscription required for advanced features like smart alerts and recorded footage starting at $4.99/month or $49.99/year.
- It shares almost all features with the wired Pro 2 model, including radar motion detection to minimize nuisance notifications.
- Other deals mentioned include the Vornado MVH Whole Room Heater for $49.99 and the Apple Watch Series 9 for $279.

items.title: Supreme Court upholds TikTok ban law
items.author: Lauren Feiner
items.summary:
- The Supreme Court ruled that a law could oust TikTok from the US unless ByteDance sells it, asserting its constitutionality.
- TikTok remains on track to be banned on January 19 unless President Biden intervenes or ByteDance sells the company.
- The court emphasized national security concerns over TikTok's data practices and foreign control.
- The ruling deemed the law as content neutral, supporting government interests without unduly burdening free expression.
- Justices expressed concerns about the speed of the proceedings and the law's content neutrality. 
- Potential buyers for TikTok are emerging, but the outcome for a sale remains uncertain amid geopolitical factors.

items.title: Cash App fined $255 million in back-to-back settlements
items.author: Mia Sato
items.summary:
- Cash App is fined $255 million due to consumer protection violations.
- Block, the parent company, will pay $80 million for not complying with regulations against illicit activities.
- Additionally, Block will pay $120 million to customers and $55 million to the CFPB for weak security measures and fraud incidents.

items.title: Maybe giant gaming handhelds are where it’s at
items.author: Antonio G. Di Benedetto
items.summary:
- The article discusses the trend of oversized gaming handhelds, specifically the Asus ROG Flow Z13 combined with a GameSir G8 Plus controller.
- The ROG Flow Z13 has a powerful AMD Strix Halo processor and provides high performance for gaming.
- Concerns are raised about the weight and handling of such large devices, which can lead to discomfort during use.
- The article explores the idea that bigger screens might be preferred in future handheld designs despite potential portability issues.
- Comparisons are made with other devices like the Nintendo Switch 2 and Acer Nitro Blaze 11, suggesting a shift in the gaming handheld market.

items.title: Nintendo’s Switch 2 is here — sort of
items.author: David Pierce
items.summary:
- The Switch 2 exists and is confirmed to be bigger than its predecessor.
- Discussion on the features and trailers released regarding the Switch 2 during an episode of The Vergecast.
- The episode also covers recent news topics including a potential TikTok ban and the impact of various tech-related legal cases.

items.title: 6 TikTok creators on where they’ll go if the app is banned
items.author: Mia Sato
items.summary:
- Creators discuss potential migration if TikTok is banned following legislative actions by President Biden.
- Many influencers are already sharing their other social account links and saying goodbye to TikTok.
- Creators like Noelle Johansen and Kay Poyer outline their plans to shift focus to platforms like Instagram, YouTube, and Bluesky.
- TikTok has become a crucial space for engagement, especially for smaller creators who rely on its unpredictability for visibility.
- Some creators express concerns about the community and connection challenges that come with moving to new platforms.
